div1.p: List of fish best suited for stocking ponds of Hydro-Electric Plants.

div1.head: Letter from H. M. Smith to Henry Rose Carter, March 4, 1915
div1.opener:
J.AM.
First
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
COMMISSIONER OF FISHERIES
WASHINGTON, D. C.
DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE
BUREAU OF FISHERIES
WASHINGTON
March 4, 1915
D
Dr. H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of February 27, you are ad-
vised that for the region from Virginia, south, the fishes
which feed on insect larvæ, best suited for stocking the
large ponds of hydro-electric plants are members of the
family of sunfishes (Centrarchidæ): the crappie (Pomoxis
sparoides), the mill-pond perch (Centrarchus macropterus),
the rock-bass (Ambloplites rupestris), the long-eared
sunfish (Lepomis auritus), and the warmouth bass Chæno-
bryttus gulosus). In addition, if there is much vegeta-
tion in the ponds, or many water-plants near the shores,
the following will be even more effective: the little
sunfishes (Enneacanthus gloriosus and obesus), and the black-
banded sunfish (Mesogonistius chætodon). In some cases it
may be desirable to introduce the fresh-water killifish
(Fundulus diaphanus), and in swamps, ditches, small creeks
or drains, the top minnows (Gambusia affinis and Heteran-
dria formosa) are excellent and will thrive in such places.

While the Bureau does not supply fishes for this pur-
2
pose, if you will furnish this office with the location
of the ponds, and the names of the representatives in
charge, it may be able to put these men in touch with
persons who will supply the necessary fishes.

The carp is of little value as a destroyer of mosqui-
to larvæ, being largely a bottom feeder. Like many other
species it undoubtedly feeds on the spawn of other fishes,
but presumably to no great extent, and it is not believed
to be generally destructive to other fishes. A relative
of the carp, the goldfish, is of value for destroying mos-
quito larvae in basins, pools, aquaria, and like places,
but is of too indolent a habit to be of much value in the
larger ponds well supplied with food.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, H. M. Smith
Commissioner.
